Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Multivariate Remote Process Sensing for Improved Observability in Injection Molding

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this collaborative research project is to significantly improve observability in polymer processing and characterize its contribution to higher product quality and manufacturing productivity. Multivariate, wireless sensors will be designed and structurally integrated into an injection mold to monitor the dynamic variations in four critical polymer states: pressure, temperature, velocity, and viscosity. An embedded ASIC chip (Application-Specific Integrated Circuit) will be incorporated within the sensor package to coordinate the multi-modal sensing actions, enable adaptive sampling rates to capture the process dynamics in an energy-efficient manner, and control the acoustic-based wireless digital transmission of the four process parameters.

If successful, the research will advance knowledge and understanding of energy harvesting means for remote sensing and the optimal interface of sensors with embedded microelectronics, in a harsh manufacturing environment. The design of the sensors represents the first system integration of piezoelectric and infrared transduction principles with mechanistic analysis, and has the potential to improve molding productivity, wherein each percentage point improvement corresponds to cost savings of over $40 million per year. Besides injection molding, the multivariate sensing platform and new analysis capability resulting from this research can be adapted across a wide array of manufacturing scenarios to improve process control and enhance quality assurance. As a result, various manufacturing operations can be better optimized and automated. The research will also contribute to multidisciplinary education and training of students at the PIs' institutions in digital sensing, multiphysics modeling, and nonlinear optimization methods.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This research investigated the feasibility, design, and use of an advanced sensor for use in plastics product manufacturing and injection molding. The motivation is to assist manufacturers to compete by making higher quality products at lower costs. Compared to existing sensors that are used in industry, this research enabled a single sensor to measure five different conditions within the manufacturing process: melt temperature, melt pressure, melt velocity, melt viscosity, and mold temperature.

The research performed advanced analysis and modeling of the included sensing elements. A thermopile was used to sense the melt temperature, so we analyzed the irradiation entering the sensor including the varying losses due to absorption and reflection. We then verified the behavior of the temperature signal output using a black box emitter. We performed similar work for acquisition of the melt pressure sensor using a piezoelectric sensor with verification of the melt pressure signal using a tensile testing machine.

Extensive validation was performed using an injection molding machine. We performed design of experiments to characterize the main effects of changes in the process including temperatures, pressures, polymer, and velocities. We measured the correlation of our sensor signals to those of the machine set-points and generally found excellent accuracy. We also developed predictive models to relate the sensor outputs to the actual quality of the products being made. We found, generally, that the multivariate sensor we developed outperformed current industry practices.

One limitation that was discovered in the research was the acquisition of process data at very fast melt velocities. When the velocity exceeded 400 mm/s, the sensor reacted too slowly to accurately capture the polymer melt velocity and viscosity. We investigated this limitation and found the characteristic response time of the thermopile was responsible. The remedy for this limitation is not so simple, however, since alternative temperature sensors (such as faster photodetectors) do not provide high fidelity signals (good responsivity) at low temperatures. Fortunately, the current sensor range of working melt velocities is sufficient for most plastics molding processes.

As a result of this research, we are seeking to license the design to sensor suppliers for broad dissemination to plastics manufacturers. We have published journal articles and presented papers so that industry can apply the developed sensing technologies and quality control approaches. Indeed, we are currently working on new standard practices for plastics manufacturers.


Last Modified: 10/03/2014
Modified by: David O Kazmer
